title: 110_hr2925
content: The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2007" establishes a grant program for gifted and talented students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This program includes authorized activities for supporting gifted and talented students. The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2007" recognizes the need to provide specialized services for gifted students from diverse backgrounds, including those with disabilities or English as a second language. Elementary school gifted students often surpass a significant portion of yearly material in various subjects. Elementary and secondary school teachers often lack training to meet the needs of gifted students. While some families can afford private programs, most high-ability students rely on public schools. Gifted education programs in public schools are crucial for students from diverse backgrounds. Parents and families play a crucial role in developing appropriate educational services for gifted students. There is no federal requirement to identify or serve the approximately 3,000,000 gifted students in the nation. Some states and local educational agencies allocate resources for gifted education, while others do not. State laws and funding for gifted education vary widely, leading to disparities in services for this special-needs population. It is crucial for more students to achieve higher levels of education to meet future economic and national security needs. US students are underrepresented in advanced degree programs, with low percentages in key fields like engineering and computer science. In the United States, twelfth-grade advanced students performed poorly in international math and science studies. Funding for gifted education is minimal, with less than 3 cents out of every $100 of the Federal K-12 education budget allocated for gifted students. If the amount appropriated under section 5468 for a fiscal year is between $7,500,000 and $57,500,000, the Secretary can award grants to State educational agencies for developing gifted education programs. If the amount exceeds $57,500,000, grants can be awarded to State educational agencies for expanding gifted education programs. Grant funds provided under this chapter can be used for activities such as providing direct educational services and materials to gifted and talented students, including curriculum compacting, modified curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment. Grant funds may also be used for the development of curriculum packages and compensation for distance learning activities. Grant funds provided under this chapter can be used for activities such as providing direct educational services and materials to gifted and talented students, including curriculum compacting, modified curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment. State educational agencies receiving grants may use up to 10% of funds for dissemination of program information, technical assistance, monitoring and evaluation, and parental education support. State educational agencies can use up to 50% of grant funds for administrative costs. SEC. 5467A. ALLOTMENTS TO STATES. The Secretary reserves 1/2 of 1 percent of funds for programs in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The remaining funds are allotted to states based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. No state may receive less than 1/2 of 1 percent. The Secretary reserves 1/2 of 1 percent of funds for programs in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. States based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. If any State does not apply for an allotment, the Secretary shall reallot the amount to the remaining States. "State application for funds is outlined in SEC. 5467B, with allotments based on populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. Unclaimed funds from States will be reallotted to others." To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with assurances that funds will support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, with unclaimed funds used for competitive grants to local educational agencies. The State educational agency must use funds to supplement, not replace, state and local funds for gifted and talented students. They must provide matching funds of at least 10% of the grant amount and develop program assessment models for accountability. The Secretary will approve state applications that meet the requirements of the chapter. "State educational agencies must allocate 90% of funds to local educational agencies through a competitive process for grants to carry out authorized activities. Grants should meet the needs of students served. Local agencies must submit applications for approval." To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a local educational agency must submit an application to the State educational agency. The application must include assurances that funds will support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, a plan to meet their educational needs, and a commitment to use funds appropriately. The local educational agency must assure that funds received will supplement, not replace, existing funds for the education and services of gifted and talented students. The State educational agency must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the number of students served and activities supported with funds under the Gifted and Talented Students Education Act. Recipients of funds can serve gifted students alongside those with similar educational needs. The term 'gifted and talented' is defined under applicable State law or by the State educational agency or local educational agency if the State does not have a specific definition. The term 'State' is defined as each of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. Authorization of appropriations for the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program is set at $170,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012. $7,500,000 is allocated for chapter A, with the remainder for chapter 2. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. In section 5461 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, the term "This part" is replaced with "This chapter". The term "this part" is also replaced with "this chapter" throughout the document. Additionally, in section 5464, subsection (c) is removed, and subsections (d) and (e) are redesignated as subsections (c) and (d), respectively.
